| Orbital_Insertion_Date = Orbits = 30â70 km polar orbit, extended mission

| Atlas V 401 Carrier_Rocket = Launch_Site = Space Launch Complex 41 Cape
| Canaveral Air Force Station Mission_Duration = one year, extended mission of
| up to five years elapsed: NSSDC_ID = 2009-031A Mass = 1,846 kg Power =
| 1,850 W Batteries = Orbit_regime = orbit_altitude = Longitude = Semimajor_Axis
| = Eccentricity = Inclination = Orbital_Period = Apoapsis = Periapsis = Orbits
| Daily = Repetitivity = Main_Instruments = Transponders = Coverage = Resolution
| = Swath = Spectral_Band = Data_rate = SSR = IMG_Resolution = Refs = Webpage =
| http://lunar.gsfc.nasa.gov/
}} The 'Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter' ('LRO') is a NASA robotic spacecraft
currently orbiting the Moon on a low polar mapping orbit. {{citation
| url=http://lroc.sese.asu.edu/whereislro/ title=Where is LRO right now?
}} The LRO mission is a precursor to future manned missions to the Moon by
NASA. To this end a detailed mapping program will identify safe landing sites,
locate potential resources on the Moon, characterize the radiation environment,
and demonstrate new technology. {{citation
|url=http://lunar.gsfc.nasa.gov/mission.html |title=LRO Mission Overview |accessdate=2009-10-
03 }} {{Cite web
| url=http://lunar.gsfc.nasa.gov/library/IAC-07-C1_7_06.pdf title=Mission design
| and operation considerations for NASA's Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter accessdate=2008-02-
| 10 publisher=Goddard Space Flight Center
|format=PDF }}

The probe will make a 3-D map of the Moon's surface and has provided some of the
first images of Apollo equipment left on the Moon.
{{Cite web
| url=http://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2005/11jul_lroc.htm title=Abandoned
| Spaceships date=11 July 2005 first=Ron last=Koczor publisher=NASA accessdate=5
| August 2009
}} {{Cite web
| url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/LRO/multimedia/lroimages/apollosites.ht-
| ml title=LROC images of Apollo sites first=Robert last=Garner publisher=NASA
| date=17 July 2009 accessdate=5 August 2009
}} The first images from LRO were published on 2 July 2009, showing a
region in the lunar highlands south of Mare Nubium (Sea of Clouds).
{{Cite web
| url = http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/LRO/multimedia/lroimages/lroc_2009070-
| 2_a.html title = LRO's First Moon Images publisher=NASA first=Robert
| last=Garner date=2 July 2009 accessdate=5 August 2009
}}

Launched on 18 June 2009, {{Cite web | url =
http://lunar.gsfc.nasa.gov/launch.html
| title = Lunar Reconnaissance Orbiter Launch publisher=Goddard Space Flight
| Center accessdate = 2008-03-22
}} in conjunction with the Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite
(LCROSS), as the vanguard of NASA's Lunar Precursor Robotic Program,
{{Cite web
| url = http://moon.msfc.nasa.gov/background.html title = Lunar Precursor
| Robotic Program: Overview & History first=Brian last=Mitchell publisher = NASA
| accessdate=5 August 2009
}} this is the first United States mission to the Moon in over ten
years. {{Cite news
| last = Dunn first = Marcia title = NASA launches unmanned Moon shot, first
| in decade agency=Associated Press publisher=ABC News date = 18 June 2009
| url =http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/wireStory?id=7870018 accessdate =5
| August 2009
}}  LRO and LCROSS are the first missions launched as part of the United
States's Vision for Space Exploration program.

The total cost of the mission is reported as US$583 million, of which $504
million pertains to the main LRO probe and $79 million to the LCROSS
satellite.
